string_table.string: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

terms.term: Word that describes a noun (e.g. in ‘blue moon’, ‘blue’ is the adjective—it describes the noun ‘moon’)
Word used to modify a verb or adjective (e.g. in ‘running fast’, ‘fast’ is the adverb—it tells you how the ‘running’ was done)
Part of a complex sentence that could function as its own sentence (e.g. ‘I got up and then I went to work.’ contains 2 clauses: I got up. I went to work.)
All online information, services, transactions, payments, forms, documents, images, video, audio, etc.
Hyperlink—a clickable link from one web page (or other digital asset) to another

Metadata is loosely defined as ‘data about data’. Web page metadata includes things like ‘page title’ and ‘description’ and is used by search engines—with other factors—to determine a page’s search ranking. It can also be used by databases and other information systems to create dynamic content
Nouns formed from verbs (e.g. ‘dictation’ is formed from ‘dictate’)
A name for a person, place, object or concept (e.g. ‘James’, ‘Sydney’, ‘diary’, ‘reluctance’)

A cluster of words related to a headword (e.g. [headwords bolded] ‘big broken-down rusty car’ is a noun phrase; ‘burned his mouth on the hot burrito’ is a verb phrase; ‘into the black abyss’ is a prepositional phrase). There can be phrases within phrases
A group of letters put before a word to change its meaning (e.g. in ‘unhappy’, the prefix is ‘un’)
Function words indicating where nouns are in relation to other nouns (e.g. in ‘the book is on the table’, ‘on’ is a preposition)
Word used as a place-holder for a noun (e.g. in ‘Bill has painted the house and now he is going to dig the trench’, ‘he’ is a pronoun for ‘Bill’)
A person, place, event, or other thing of which there is only one—generally with initial capitals (e.g. Mary, Brisbane, Soundwave)
The entire single website experience—including business.qld.gov.au
A group of letters put after a word to change its meaning (e.g. in ‘payment’, the suffix is ‘ment’)
Uniform resource locator—the ‘address’ of a web page on the internet (e.g. http://www.qld.gov.au)
A website is a collection of related web pages, or other digital assets, available on the internet. Generally, web pages belonging to a website will share a common URL
